ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Detailed grammar of Korean, lots of context of Korea such as canonical literature, history both modern contemporary and older. Speaking Korean in a formal manner.
Advanced grammar, vocabulary, and Korean history, literature, and societal issues

I improved my Korean writing skills through learning more advanced vocabulary and especially more advanced writing structure and grammar. I also practiced reading advanced texts such as newspaper articles in Korean and learned about Korean history, current issues, as well as studying a short story.
I learned about nuanced aspects of Korean grammar and also an overall timeline of Korean history.
I learned general history of modern Korea (from around Joseon dynasty to present day). I became introduced to formal grammar.

This course developed my reading, writing, and comprehension abilities in the Korean language. The course was especially helpful for reading and writing, as most of the assignments were writing-based.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very good at getting students engaged in the topic and learning about Korean culture and history. However, the class was not super engaging.

Strengths of this course is that it covers a lot of interesting content on Korea so there is something for everyone, including literature, history, current affairs, and more. Class this semester was apparently slightly larger than a normal class, it was great to discuss with others.
Course could be improved by perhaps slightly more speaking engagements but I think it was more difficult because of the online format.

Choi SSN did a great job of selecting interesting articles that challenged us by expanding our vocabulary use and knowledge of formal writing structures. Each week was dedicated to a different topic, so we learned a wide breadth of new terminologies that allow us to engage in deeper conversations about politics, history, culture, etc.

Strengths: The variety of material and content we covered and I definitely had a lot of practice strengthening my writing skills and enhancing my vocabulary. 
Weaknesses: The structure of the course was sometimes a bit more fluid and uncertain at times but that also was because the class had to cater to a variety of skill levels and interests.

This course provided a strong structure for practicing writing skills and learning new vocabulary and grammar, as well as learning about important topics in Korean current events and history. I wish the workload had been more evenly spread - there were intense reading and writing assignments at the beginning of the semester, but they tapered off towards the end of the semester, and I think I would have remembered more vocabulary with more consistent practice.

Strengths: High engagement, lots of interactions between students, clear feed back 
Weakness: Lack of concrete structure

The difficultly with higher level language classes is that the students' language abilities differ more than in introductory classes. This course could be improved by not tailoring to any one end of the range (often, I felt that the course material was fit for the students who were already fluent at Korean). The material was dense and often more academic than realistic, as in the wording of readings were not common to what is truly used in society. Strengths is that the Professor goes through, line by line, the dense class material and is willing to repeat explanations. And there is also a TA session to ask specific questions about that week's readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Some technical issues for both students and teacher,  but overall it was good.

Going through texts together over Zoom using screen sharing worked well. I wish we had access to the presentations on the historical topics that were given in class. Discussions in the breakout rooms were helpful, and I especially liked larger group discussions rather than pair discussions. We had some trouble trying to watch a movie together over Zoom.

Answering reading questions through randomized break-out rooms helped to get to know my other classmates as well as encourage discussion. What could be improved is Professors directing questions at specific students rather than the broadly to the entire class, since often through Zoom there is an awkward barrier to unmute oneself and answer the question out loud. I think using the Zoom survey function or encouraging answering through the chat box is helpful for more shy students to participate in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially if you want to improve on Korean vocab.
Definitely! Great course to take that regardless of your Korean level you will improve.
Yes, I would recommend to anyone who is looking to improve their Korean from an intermediate to advanced level

I would recommend this course to students who want to improve their writing and expand their vocabulary as well as learn about Korean modern history and modern societal issues more broadly. I would not recommend this course to students who want to improve their speaking though there was some opportunity to practice that but there was more emphasis on writing skills.

Yes, if you are looking to improve your Korean reading and writing this is a good course to take. If you are looking to focus more on speaking, you will get practice in this course, but it is definitely not the focus.
Yes, especially if they want to learn more than just the language of Korean
Take this course if you are fluent/comfortable with Korean and want to get the language credit.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Live weekly one-on-one meeting with TA
The course was a live virtual seminar with virtual weekly office hours, and included homework and quizzes that students submitted through Canvas.
